Welcome to Z Hotel Bath, UK
===========================
Relax in Bath’s spas in a city rich in history and Georgian Architecture
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Famous for its Thermae Spa and healing waters, quaint charm with a focus on wellbeing, Bath will leave you feeling enriched and renewed. Our 149-bed hotel is just a few minutes’ walk from the Roman Baths. Once you’ve dipped your toe into the hot springs, you can immerse yourself in the 18th-century delights of this city, from the works of Jane Austen to the gorgeous Georgian architecture. The nearest car park is located on Charlotte Street BA1 2NE (5 minutes’ walk).
1.  Bath Spa 8 minutes
### Bath at a glance
*   Georgian architecture of the Royal Crescent
*   Literary pride at Jane Austen Centre
*   Historic bathing at Roman Baths and Pump Room
*   Entertaining Theatre Royal
*   Sunset soaks in natural thermal waters
*   Thriving arts and cultural scene
*   Beloved Sally Lunn buns
Our Rooms
---------
Step into your home from home as soon as you open the door to your Z room.  Our rooms in the heart of central London have been cleverly designed to provide you with everything you need for your stay with us.  You’ll find sumptuous beds, beautiful crisp linen, with en-suite showers, HDTV with all channels and Sky & TNT Sports and of course WiFi.  We also offer complimentary toiletries, hanging space, underbed storage and in-room tea and coffee making – at Z...[Content truncated]

metatags.og:title: Bathhouse - Rockwell Group
metatags.og:description: ​Rockwell Group designed Bathhouse’s second location, a three-level oasis in Manhattan that takes guests on a hero’s journey.

website_content.content:
Bathhouse - Rockwell Group
===============
=======================================================
Menu
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
Spa
Bathhouse
---------
New York, NY
* * *
Bathhouse is a distinct departure from traditional wellness models, filling a niche at the intersection of a no-frills banya and a luxury spa. Our design concept for the first Manhattan location—a three-level destination featuring thermal pools, saunas, and marble hammams—was inspired by the idea of the Hero’s Journey. Our goal was to create a new architectural language, allowing guests to feel as though they’ve discovered a slightly futuristic ruin from an ancient civilization.
Answering the call to adventure.
--------------------------------
!
At reception, portals of fluted glass emphasize the guests’ journey to come.
!
Guests descend a black stair to a vestibule with a mural by Dean Barger, one of many thresholds.
!
Black, mirrored portals create rhythm in the locker rooms.
!
Guests begin on the ground floor and descend down two subterranean levels, passing through a series of portals in a dream-like environment.
!
Six pools in a range of temperatures are lit in different tones (cooler to warmer).
!
Glowing fields of colored lights ascend to unknown depths above the pools.
!
As guests emerge from the locker rooms, they enter the lounge and café for a moment of reprieve.
A ceremonial sauna is lined in cedar with an altar-like central heater. Sauna Masters perform Aufguss, a sensory experience with scented oils, music, and, of course, heat.
!
!
The steam room is clad in Danish three-dimensional tile with strips of light for a mysterious focal point.
!
Inner sanctum
-------------
* * *
A darkened, compressed corridor evokes a sense of anticipation on the way to the treatment rooms. Guests emerge into a small lounge area with another pyramid hovering over salt pool, and a travertine gradient feature wall.
What’s Going On
Article
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Surface 02.08.24
!
Article
----------------------------------------------------------------...[Content truncated]

metatags.og:title: Buildings and architecture of Bath - Wikipedia

website_content.content:
[Content truncated]... World Heritage Site in 1987, largely because of its architectural history and the way in which the city landscape draws together public and private buildings and spaces. The many examples of Palladian architecture are purposefully integrated with the urban spaces to provide "picturesque aestheticism". In 2021, the city was added to a second World Heritage Site, a group of historic spa towns across Europe known as the "Great Spas of Europe". Bath is the only entire city in Britain to achieve World Heritage status, and is a popular tourist destination.
Important buildings include the Roman Baths; neoclassical architect Robert Adam's Pulteney Bridge, based on an unused design for the Rialto Bridge in Venice; and Bath Abbey in the city centre, founded in 1499 on the site of an 8th-century church. Of equal importance are the residential buildings designed and built into boulevards and crescents by the Georgian architects John Wood, the Elder and his son John Wood, the Younger – well-known examples being the Royal Crescent, built around 1770, and The Circus, built around 1760, where each of the three curved segments faces one of the entrances, ensuring that there is always a classical facade facing the entering visitor.
Most of Bath's buildings are made from the local, golden-coloured, Bath Stone. The dominant architectural style is Georgian, which evolved from the Palladian revival style that became popular in the early 18th century. The city became a fashionable and popular spa and social centre during the 18th century. Based initially around its hot springs, this led to a demand for substantial homes and guest houses. The key architects, John Wood and his son, laid out many of the city's present-day squares and crescents within a green valley and the surrounding hills. According to UNESCO this provided... "an integration of architecture, urban design, and landscape setting, and the deliberate creation of a beautiful city". Development during modern eras, including the development of the transport infrastructure and rebuilding after bomb damage during World War II, has mostly been in keeping with earlier styles to maintain the integrated cityscape.
Celtic, Roman and Saxon
The Great Bath at the Roman Baths. The entire structure above the level of the pillar bases is a later construction.
Buildings from Bath's pre-Norman period either no longer exist, or their remains are below street level. Archaeological sites in the central area of the city have supplied some details about how they may have looked, while the lower areas of the Roman...[Content truncated]

metatags.og:title: Lost Buildings - Palm Springs Modern Committee

website_content.content:
### Spa Bathhouse and Hotel
#### Demolished 2014
The Spa Bathhouse and Hotel was designed in 1955, a collaboration by noted modern architects , , Richard Harrison and Phillip Koenig. One of the most striking features of the building’s design was its graceful, concrete-domed colonnade which lead visitors diagonally to the Bathhouse.
The Agua Caliente Band of Cahuilla Indians who own the property, announced plans to demolish the Spa Bathhouse and Hotel in its entirety and PS ModCom established a dialog and presented a case for restoration instead. In the midst of these discussions the Tribe demolished the buildings in June 2014.
Images © J. PAUL GETTY TRUST. USED WITH  
PERMISSION. JULIUS SHULMAN ARCHIVE
### PSHS Administration Building
#### Demolished 2012
Despite extensive testimony and effort by the preservation community, the Palm Springs Unified School District (PSUSD) voted to demolish its modern Administration Building designed in 1957 by the renowned local architectural firm of Wexler & Harrison for a performing arts building. In addition, the funding for the new building was approved by the California State Allocation Board.
The Administration Building was a fine example of mid-century modern design with few alterations. Its demolition versus implementing an adaptive reuse as a portion of a performing arts building is tragic and disturbing.
!
Images © Dan Chavkin
### Chart House, Rancho Mirage
#### Arson 2012, Demolished 2013
On February 7, 2013 the Rancho Mirage City Council denied the Palm Springs Modern Committee’s appeal of the City’s order to demolish the Chart House restaurant, which had been damaged by fire in...[Content truncated]

How do modern spa experiences reflect ancient Roman bathing traditions?
Why is preserving historical Roman baths important for today’s culture?
How do modern wellness facilities incorporate the legacy of Roman spas?

creativework.headline: Roman Baths: A Dive into Ancient Luxury Spa

website_content.content:
[Content truncated]... the magnitude of these communal spaces, one need only look at the archaeological remains of renowned sites such as those in Bath, England. These ruins stand as a testament to the grandeur and significance of the institution throughout classical antiquity.
> The public baths were not just places of hygiene but were intricately woven into the social and cultural fabric of the time—a true reflection of lifestyle and luxury.
Below is a summarized glimpse into the various functions of the Roman baths and how they served as precursors to our modern-day spas:
| Purpose of Roman Baths | Contemporary Spa Equivalent |
| --- | --- |
| Hygiene and Cleansing | Detoxification Therapies |
| Leisure and Relaxation | Wellness and Relaxation Packages |
| Socializing and Networking | Spa Social Lounges |
| Therapeutic Routines | Therapeutic Water Treatments |
| Display of Wealth and Power | Luxury Spa Amenities |
Roman baths functioned within a society that valued not just cleanliness but also the holistic nourishment of body and soul. This philosophy laid the groundwork for the all-encompassing spa experiences that are highly sought after in our time. The heritage of ancient baths—where the air was steeped in essential oils, and the corridors echoed with conversations of literature, politics, and commerce—continues to inspire our quest for serene sanctuaries of well-being.
Architectural Marvels: The Design and Construction of Ancient Bathhouses
------------------------------------------------------------------------
The sophisticated design of **ancient bathhouse architecture** stands as a testament to the innovative spirit of the bygone eras, especially within the Roman Empire. The intricacy of **Roman aqueducts** and **heating methodologies** not only highlights their engineering prowess but also their dedication to creating spaces of relaxation and socialization. Let’s delve into the elements that made these structures timeless treasures in architectural history.
### Advanced Aqueduct Systems
Roman engineers revolutionized the way water was supplied to bathhouses by constructing elaborate aqueducts. These feats of engineering spanned great distances, carrying fresh water from mountain springs or lakes directly into the urban heart. The aqueducts not only supplied water for bathing but also for drinking and irrigation, thus sustaining the bustling life of the city. The enormity and precision of these systems illustrated both the ambition and the technical capabilities of ancient Rome.
!(blob:https://roman-empire.net/f19e56331cf34a059197d5fb5b6082dc)
### Heating Techniques and Hypocausts
Perhaps even more impressive than the aqueducts was the method of heating these grand spaces. The Romans employed hypocaust systems, which constituted an early form of central heating. These systems involved a raised floor,...[Content truncated]

Stainless Steel Hot Tubs
------------------------
Diamond Spas believe metal is the best construction material for . Stainless steel hot tubs or copper spas yields amenities that rival other spas. Unmatched durability is number one. Neither metal will fade, crack or blister. Additionally, all stainless steel spas are TIG welded promising years of leak-tight enjoyment. A stainless steel hot tub or stainless steel spa are highly sanitary and both surfaces offer superior resistance to bacteria. Metal aesthetically blends harmoniously with common spa landscaping materials. Natural stone and foliage in combination with the warm tones of these two metals contrive an environment appealing to all the senses. Stainless steel and copper construct . Not only will they avoid the landfills, but they will also bring the client a nice return on their original investment. Diamond Spas fabricates custom stainless steel pools and stainless steel hot tubs that are not only innovative they are smart for both the consumer and the environment.
Eco-friendly & Sustainable
--------------------------
Diamond Spas builds eco-friendly spas and pools. Our chlorine-free luxury hot tubs and pools reduce the amount...[Content truncated]
